title: Annee de Mamiel
description: Annee de Mamiel runs her skincare product company de Mamiel and injects it with copious amounts of woo and exorbitant prices. Her products supposedly are more effective — they gain more "vitality" — because she puts them near crystals, and chants to them, and plays music to them. There's no evidence for this, but it sure does market well.
cleaned_text: ""It's about doing anything to increase the energy of the products. [....] We are emotional, physical, and chemical beings—it's about having the oils be the most vital they can be. People sense and appreciate it, whether they know why or not. |—de Mamiel, demonstrating textbook | Annee de Mamiel runs her skincare product company de Mamiel and injects it with copious amounts of [woo](/wiki/Woo) and exorbitant prices. Her products supposedly are more effective — they gain more "vitality" — because she [puts them near crystals](/wiki/Crystal_woo), and [chants to them](/wiki/Faith_healing), and [plays music to them](/wiki/Sound_healing). There's no evidence for this, but it sure does market well. History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Annee_de_Mamiel&action=edit§ion=1)] de Mamiel originally worked in finance, until the death of her boss. In 1998, she was diagnosed with [cancer](/wiki/Cancer). To reduce the effects of chemotherapy on her skin, and [because she felt that chemotherapy was "unnatural"](/wiki/Appeal_to_nature), she began creating her own natural skin products. She later studied [Traditional Chinese Medicine](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_Medicine), [acupuncture](/wiki/Acupuncture), [aromatherapy](/wiki/Aromatherapy), and [chiropractic](/wiki/Chiropractic) which are considered [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine). She appears to actively practice acupuncture and TCM in London. Other product problems[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Annee_de_Mamiel&action=edit§ion=3)] ""Because, as we all know, applying lotion to your body is pointless unless it has been treated with |—| The woo doesn't stop there. "Holistic"[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Annee_de_Mamiel&action=edit§ion=4)] de Mamiel promotes her oils as ["holistic" or "syngetistic"](/wiki/Holistic_medicine). For example: Seasonal Facial Oils offer a new take on ageing by treating skin holistically because what is happening inside and around us will reflect on our faces. I personally select each plant extract in these precious oils and hand blend them so they work synergistically with mind and skin, putting back what nature and our lifestyles take away. [[17]] It is unclear how de Mamiel's mass-marketed skin lotion can be any more "holistic" (specific to a patient, and inclusive of the entirety of what ails them) than any other mass-marketed skin lotion. "Cleanse"[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Annee_de_Mamiel&action=edit§ion=5)] de Mamiel offers numerous products. [[18]](#cite_note-C1-18) [[19]](#cite_note-C2-19) [[20]](#cite_note-20) Given that most "cleanse" products claim to remove a " [toxin](/wiki/Toxin)" from the body, yet de Mamiel's products remain on the body (and would eventually move into it), it's unclear what it's cleansing, or how. Spirits[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Annee_de_Mamiel&action=edit§ion=6)] She constantly appeals to the human " [spirit](/wiki/Spirit)" (yet she simultaneously fails to prove that one exists, or that her cleanses actually impact the soul): My lifeline for a tired body and a spent spirit, I use this rich, glimmering serum in the evenings to bring a sense of calmness, to nourish and deeply moisturise my skin and soul. I added a subtle shimmer to Revitalising Body Serum for a sense of glamour - it is my ultimate mind and body treatment. [[21]] Nature![ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Annee_de_Mamiel&action=edit§ion=7)] Above all else, she [glorifies anything "natural"](/wiki/Appeal_to_nature), as if it was somehow better: My brand is not just about how to apply the products to your skin, but how to reduce stress in your life. We've cut ourselves off from what mother nature is doing. All the people I treat live in an artificial environment - artificial heat, cold and light. Many people are stressed from this and there's no sense of belonging to natural environments. I create small rituals to help us through that process. [[2]] The ingredients in our products are naturally sourced and blended in small quantities which may result in some slight variations in colour and aroma from time to time. This is one of mother nature's subtleties which we wholeheartedly embrace. [[22]] She does at least warn that nature isn't all-good: One can have a reaction to a natural product as easily as a synthetic one. In fact, essential oils can cause some of the most common allergic reactions, which is why, when working with them, you really need to know what you're doing, not just mix them up and hope for the best!
